questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optic nerve invasion Direct spread to the optic nerve and brain is the most common mode of spread of Retinoblastoma . Retinoblastoma arises from the neurosensory retina. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children . It is composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm. May present with:- Leukocoria Convergent or divergent squint Cataract Buphthalmos Hypopyon Proptosis Stages of retinoblastoma Quiescent stage – last from 6 months to 1 year Glaucomatous stage Stage of extra ocular extension Stage of metastasis

Highyeild:

Histology: Tumor composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts) with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm Many retinoblastomas are undifferentiated but differentiation are characterized by formation of rosettes , of which there are 3 types - Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes Homer-Wright rosettes Fleurettes Endophytic Growth Pattern:- White to cream-colored mass breaks through internal limiting membrane No surface vessels or small, irregular tumor vessels Associated with vitreous seeding Exophytic Growth Pattern:- Yellow-white lesion in subretinal space Overlying retinal vessels increased in caliber and tortuosity Associated subretinal fluid and RD that can obscure the tumour

Extraedge:

Treatment Small Tumor (<3mm wide × 2mm thick) - Laser photocoagulation - Transpupillary thermotherapy - Cryotherapy Medium tumours (12mm wide × 6mm thick) - Brachytherapy - Primary Chemotherapy (CEV) - External beam radiotherapy Large tumours - Chemotherapy followed by local treatment - Enucleation Extraocular extension - Adjuvant chemotherapy - External beam radiotherapy Metastatic disease - Chemotherapy

questions.text: There is a Proptosis in a child with a desmin positive tumor. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma The proptosis and desmin positive tumor suggests diagnosis of Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma . Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. There are 4 types of Rhabdomyosarcoma : Embryonal – Best prognosis Alveolar Pleomorphic Spindle cell/sclerosing Among the Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma , the best prognosis is of Sarcoma botryoides. This occurs in the walls of hollow , mucosa lined structures like:- nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder and vagina with cambium layer. Rhabdomyosarcoma is positive for:- desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1 and Leukaemia – CD34 + Lymphoma – CD45+, CD 34 – Ewing's sarcoma – CD 99 +, S100+

Highyeild:

Zones of loose & dense cellularity remarkably recapitulate normal embryonic myogenesis , in which loose primitive mesenchyme condenses to form nascent muscle exhibit all cellular phases of myogenesis dense condensations of rhabdomyoblasts amid foci with a loose myxoid stroma. They share features with other embryonal neoplasms of childhood , such as:- Wilms tumors, hepatoblastomas, pancreatoblastoma, and neuroblastomas

Extraedge:

EMBRYONAL Favorable clinical outcome Affect younger male patients Most commonly arise in the head, neck, and genitourinary regions Loss of heterozygosity at the imprinted 11p15 locus Loss of the maternal allele and duplication of the paternal allele Encodes the IGF-2 growth factor

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left occipital lobe The given image of the visual field shows right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. It is caused by the lesion in the left occipital lobe. This lesion occurs due to the occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery . The macular sparing occurs because the part of the visual cortex representing central macular vision is supplied by a branch of middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery (macula have double blood supply).

Highyeild:

Visual field defect Homonymous hemianopia congruous - either occipital lobe Hemiachromatopsia (color vision) precedes black and white vision loss Central hemianopia - occipital pole Bilateral central hemianopia - both occipital pole Quadrant and altitudinal defect - one side of calcarine fissure

Extraedge:

Balint Syndrome An inability to look voluntarily into the peripheral field , with normal eye movements (psychic paralysis of fixation gaze) A failure to precisely grasp or touch an object under visual guidance, hand and eyes in-coordinated (optic ataxia) Prosopognosia Cannot identify familiar face , can point out its features Cannot learn new faces Difficulty in interpreting meaning of facial expression, gender and age May identify by other feature like moustache, gait, spectacle or sound of voice

Table:

#MANTRA

Solution:

Pleomorphic adenoma Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal

Highyeild:

Clinical features: Painless slowly progressive proposis or swelling in the superolateral eyelid a smooth, firm, non-tender mass in the lacrimal gland fossa inferonasal dystopia Investigation : CT shows a round or oval mass , with a smooth outline and indentation but not destruction of the lacrimal gland fossa. The lesion may indent the globe , and calcification may be shown .

Extraedge:

Main lacrimal gland: Non-capsulated multilobular sector structure Situated in the fossa for lacrimal gland Divided into 2 parts:- Superior orbital part Inferior palpebral part Ducts : 10-12 ducts open into superior for 1-2 ducts open into inferior fornix

questions.text: Identify the condition in the given image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oculomotor nerve palsy The given image shows ptosis and down and out left eye that indicates third nerve palsy (oculomotor palsy) of the left side.

Highyeild:

Syndromes of Fascicular lesion Benedikt syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral extrapyramidal signs Weber syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis Nothnagel syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and cerebellar ataxia SIGNS Ptosis Abduction of globe Intorsion of the globe which increases on attempted down gaze Limitation of adduction Limitation of elevation Limitation of depression Dilated pupil with defective accommodation

Extraedge:

Causes of isolated 3rd nerve palsy Idiopathic - about 25% Vascular - Hypertension & Diabetes (commonly pupil sparing) Aneurysm - posterior communicating artery at its junction with internal carotid artery Trauma - subdural hematoma with uncal herniation Miscellaneous SYMPTOMS Drooping of eyelid Binocular double vision Pain (may be present)

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: SAFE strategy for trachoma includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Evaluation of program Evaluation of the program is not included in the SAFE strategy. E in the SAFE strategy stand for Environmental cleanliness SAFE Strategy S – Surgery – Trichiasis and Entropion correction surgery – Tertiary prevention A – Antibiotics – Oral Azithromycin, Topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% Azithromycin – Secondary prevention F – Facial hygiene – Primary prevention E – Environmental cleanliness – Primordial prevention

Highyeild:

Signs - Upper tarsal conjunctiva - mc affected, appears red velvety, congested Trachomatous follicle - essential lesion , upto 5mm size characteristic distribution - upper fornix(mc), upper margin of tarsus, palpebral conjunctiva Scarring of conjunctiva Arlt's line Limbal follicles Herbert pits - oval/pitted scars in limbus

Extraedge:

WHO CLASSIFICATION(FISTO) TRACHOMATOUS FOLLICULAR(TF) Active disease 5 or more follicles of › 0.5mm on upper tarsus Deep conjunctival vessels seen If treated properly- no scarring TRACHOMA INTENSE Severe disease, needs urgents rx diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present TRACHOMATOUS SCARRING- Inactive infection conjunctival scarring visible fibrous white bands on tarsal conjunctiva TRACHOMATOUS TRICHIASIS Needs corrective surgery CORNEAL OPACITY sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: Identify the structure located at the level of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked in this image.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Red nucleus In the given image, the medial rectus muscle is marked. The medial rectus is supplied by the third nerve nucleus. Red nucleus is present at the level of the third nerve nucleus in the midbrain .

Highyeild:

Syndromes of Fascicular lesion Benedikt syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral extrapyramidal signs Weber syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis Nothnagel syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and cerebellar ataxia SIGNS Ptosis Abduction of globe Intorsion of the globe which increases on attempted down gaze Limitation of adduction Limitation of elevation Limitation of depression Dilated pupil with defective accommodation

Extraedge:

Nucleus Located in midbrain at the level of superior colliculus, ventral to the Sylvian aqueduct. Composed of:- Unpaired levator subnucleus Paired superior rectus subnucleus Paired medial rectus, inferior rectus and inferior oblique subnuclei Unpaired Edinger-Westphal nucleus
